definitions.definition: To constrain someone by force or by social, moral or legal means.
definitions.example: I am obliged to report to the police station every week.

definitions.definition: To do (someone) a service or favour (hence, originally, creating an obligation).
definitions.example: He obliged me by not parking his car in the drive.

definitions.definition: To be indebted to someone.
definitions.example: I am obliged to you for your recent help.

definitions.definition: Under an obligation to do something for someone.
Indebted because of a favor done.
(of a person) Having affection or warm regard; loving; fond.
definitions.example: She eulogised her always warm and affectionate brother.

definitions.definition: (of an action, etc.) Characterised by or proceeding from affection; indicating love; tender.
definitions.example: the affectionate care of a parent; an affectionate countenance; an affectionate message; affectionate language

definitions.definition: Eager; passionate; strongly inclined toward something.
To show affection to; to have affection for.
To emotionally attach (oneself) to.
A dog of a particular breed originating in Germany.
Any of the eight-legged creatures, including spiders and scorpions, of the class Arachnida.
An ox-like mammal native to the Himalayas, Mongolia, Burma, and Tibet with dark, long, and silky hair, a horse-like tail, and a full, bushy mane.
A talk, particular an informal talk; chattering; gossip.
A laugh.
Vomit.
To talk, particularly informally but persistently; to chatter or prattle.
To vomit, usually as a result of excessive alcohol consumption.
A kayak.
Causing, feeling, or expressing regret or sorrow, especially in a wry or humorous way.
Inspiring pity or compassion.
Bad; woeful; deplorable.
A mediaeval and Renaissance wind instrument.
A stop on an organ.
Tending to talk a lot.
Speaking openly and honestly, neglecting privacy and consequences.
An accessible structure extending from a building, especially outside a window.
An accessible structure overlooking a stage or the like.
A secondary product; something made incidentally during the production of something else.
A side effect.
definitions.example: The many Indian restaurants all over Britain are a by-product of the large waves of immigration from the subcontinent.

definitions.definition: To declare or find innocent or not guilty.
To discharge (for example, a claim or debt); to clear off, to pay off; to fulfil.
Followed by of (and formerly by from): to discharge, release, or set free from a burden, duty, liability, or obligation, or from an accusation or charge.
definitions.example: The jury acquitted the prisoner of the charge.

definitions.definition: To bear or conduct oneself; to perform one's part.
definitions.example: The orator acquitted himself very poorly.

definitions.definition: To clear oneself.
To release, to rescue, to set free.
To pay for; to atone for.
Not contested or disputed; not made the object of competition.
To engage in trade; to carry on commerce.
To engage in in-store promotion of the sale of goods, as by display and arrangement of goods.
definitions.example: He started his career merchandising in a small clothing store chain.

definitions.definition: To engage in the trade of.
To engage in in-store promotion of the sale of.
definitions.example: He got hired to merchandise some new sporting goods lines.

definitions.definition: To promote as if for sale.
definitions.example: The record companies don't get as good a return on merchandising artists under contract.

definitions.definition: Trade in merchandise
To gently satirize.
To deceive.
To falsify.
To ejaculate, to come.

A method of attacking a computer program, in which the program is modified so as to appear to be working normally when in reality it has been modified with the purpose of circumventing security mechanisms.
Phishing.
To remove the head of; to cut someone's head off.
Any of several species of large sea mammals of the infraorder Cetacea.
Something, or someone, that is very large.
Something, or someone, that is excellent.
In a casino, a person who routinely bets at the maximum limit allowable.
An investor who deals with very large amounts of money.
(by extension) A video game player who spends large amounts of money on premium content.
To hunt for whales.
To thrash, to flog, to beat vigorously or soundly.
To do bookkeeping.
The skill or practice of keeping books or systematic records of financial transactions, e.g. income and expenses.
General tasks for maintaining a system.
A mild rebuke, or an implied criticism.
Disgrace or shame.
An object of scorn.
To criticize or rebuke (someone).
To disgrace, or bring shame upon.
Any highly technical or specialized technological application or equipment, especially one that involves complex electronics or computing
A security or guarantee (usually an asset) pledged for the repayment of a loan if one cannot procure enough funds to repay.
(genealogy) A collateral (not linear) family member.
A branch of a bodily part or system of organs.
definitions.example: Besides the arteries blood streams through numerous veins we call collaterals.

definitions.definition: Printed materials or content of electronic media used to enhance sales of products (short form of collateral material).
A thinner blood vessel providing an alternate route to blood flow in case the main vessel becomes occluded.
A contemporary or rival.
Parallel, along the same vein, side by side.
Corresponding; accompanying, concomitant.
Being aside from the main subject, target, or goal.
definitions.example: Although not a direct cause, the border skirmish was certainly a collateral incitement for the war.

definitions.definition: (genealogy) Of an indirect ancestral relationship, as opposed to lineal descendency.
definitions.example: Uncles, aunts, cousins, nephews and nieces are collateral relatives.

definitions.definition: Relating to a collateral in the sense of an obligation or security.
Expensive to the extent of being paid through a loan.
Coming or directed along the side.
definitions.example: collateral pressure

definitions.definition: Acting in an indirect way.
(of a vascular bundle) Having the phloem and xylem adjacent.
A type of financial institution that focuses on retail banking: savings of private depositors, payments, credits and insurances for individuals or small and medium-sized enterprises.
Any of several coarse ferns, of the genus Pteridium, that form dense thickets; often poisonous to livestock.
An area of countryside heavily populated by this fern.
A deep brown colour.
Of a deep brown colour.
A legitimate; a legitimate actor.
A legitimate child.
Legitimate; legal; allowed by the rules; valid.
(by extension, of a thing or person) Genuine, actual, literal or honest.
Genuinely good and possessing all the required or expected qualities; the real deal.
definitions.example: I checked out her portfolio. She's legit.

definitions.definition: Cool by virtue of being genuine.
Legitimately; within the law.
Honestly; truly; seriously.
definitions.example: He legit thinks he can pass the test on zero sleep.

definitions.definition: The coastal land bordering a sea or an ocean.
The foreshore, the strip of land between low water and high water.
To become enraged, angry, or irritated.
To receive a red card, and be dismissed from the playing field.
Any of various academic sessions held in the summer at schools or universities when the usual students are away; either for supplementary or remedial study or as part of distance learning.
A trench cut in the soil, as when plowed in order to plant a crop.
definitions.example: Don't walk across that deep furrow in the field.

definitions.definition: Any trench, channel, or groove, as in wood or metal.
A deep wrinkle in the skin of the face, especially on the forehead.
definitions.example: When she was tired, a deep furrow appeared on her forehead.

definitions.definition: To cut one or more grooves in (the ground, etc.).
definitions.example: Cart wheels can furrow roads.

definitions.definition: To wrinkle.
To pull one's brows or eyebrows together due to concentration, worry, etc.
definitions.example: As she read the document intently her brows began to furrow.

definitions.definition: To impart motion or the appearance of motion to.
definitions.example: If we animate the model, we can see the complexity of the action.

definitions.definition: To give spirit or vigour to; to stimulate or enliven; to inspirit.
That which lives.
Possessing the quality or ability of motion.
Dynamic, energetic.
definitions.example: She is an engaging and animate speaker.

definitions.definition: (grammar, of a noun or pronoun) Having a referent that includes a human, animal, plant or other entity which is considered alive.
definitions.example: Nouns can be singular or plural, and one of two genders, animate or inanimate.

definitions.definition: (grammar) Inflected to agree with an animate noun or pronoun.
A building or institution where money (originally, only coins) is produced under government licence.
A large amount of money. A vast sum or amount, etc.
definitions.example: It must have cost a mint to produce!

definitions.definition: Any place regarded as a source of unlimited supply; the supply itself.
To reproduce (coins), usually en masse, under licence.
To invent; to forge; to fabricate; to fashion.
(with condition) Like new.
definitions.example: in mint condition.

definitions.definition: In near-perfect condition; uncirculated.
Unused with original gum; as issued originally.
Very good.
Attractive; beautiful; handsome.
Any plant in the genus Mentha in the family Lamiaceae, typically aromatic with square stems.
The flavouring of the plant, either a sweet, a jelly or sauce.
Any plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae.
A green colour, like that of mint.
A mint-flavored candy, often eaten to sweeten the smell of the breath.
Of a green colour, like that of the mint plant.
(provincial) Intent, purpose; an attempt, try; effort, endeavor.
(provincial) To try, attempt; take aim.
(provincial) To try, attempt, endeavor; to take aim at; to try to hit; to purpose.
To hint; suggest; insinuate.

In combat, the soldier who takes point; the soldier who assumes the first and most exposed position in a combat military formation; the lead soldier/unit advancing through hostile or unsecured territory.
(by extension) A most trusted assistant or associate; the person upon whom one would most rely.
A motorboat which has enclosed living quarters, especially a privately owned pleasure craft.
The quality of artistry and persuasiveness in speech or writing.
An eloquent utterance.
A sunscreen with high sun protection factor (SPF).
The increase of the rate of a chemical reaction, induced by a catalyst.
Any of several small passerine birds of the finch family
An official record indicating that two people got married on the date of the certificate.
The page, near the front of a book, that gives its title and, normally, its author and publisher
To fiddle idly.
definitions.example: The kids sat there messing around with leaves and blades of grass because they were bored.

definitions.definition: To joke, kid, or play.
definitions.example: Don't mess around with electricity if you don't understand it.

definitions.definition: To have a sexual relationship, especially one which is non-commital.
definitions.example: Rumor has it that he's messing around with his secretary.

definitions.definition: The bone of the lower jaw; the mandible.
Any of the bones in the lower or upper jaw.
(singular or plural) A shaken musical instrument (an idiophone) made from the jawbone of an animal and shaken such that the teeth vibrate in their sockets to produce sound.
To talk persistently in an attempt to persuade somebody to cooperate.
A semiprecious stone, either nephrite or jadeite, generally green or white in color, often used for carving figurines.
A bright shade of slightly bluish or greyish green, typical of polished jade stones.
A succulent plant, Crassula ovata.
Of a grayish shade of green, typical of jade stones.
A horse too old to be put to work.
A bad-tempered or disreputable woman.
To tire, weary or fatigue
To treat like a jade; to spurn.
To make ridiculous and contemptible.
An object, now especially a cloth, used for dusting surfaces etc.
Someone who dusts.
A light, loose-fitting long coat.
(paper-making) A revolving wire-cloth cylinder which removes the dust from rags, etc.
(milling) A blowing-machine for separating the flour from the bran.
(oil and gas) A dry drill hole, one that does not produce oil or gas.
A vehicle-mounted, multi-barrelled, anti-aircraft gun.
A sundress.
A block of felt strips, shaped ergonomically, used to remove chalk from a blackboard.
A high pitch toward the batter.

One of the simple machines; a piece of material, such as metal or wood, thick at one edge and tapered to a thin edge at the other for insertion in a narrow crevice, used for splitting, tightening, securing, or levering.
definitions.example: Stick a wedge under the door, will you? It keeps blowing shut.

definitions.definition: A piece (of food, metal, wood etc.) having this shape.
definitions.example: Can you cut me a wedge of cheese?

definitions.definition: A five-sided polyhedron with a rectangular base, two rectangular or trapezoidal sides meeting in an edge, and two triangular ends.
Something that creates a division, gap or distance between things.
A flank of cavalry acting to split some portion of an opposing army, charging in an inverted V formation.
A type of iron club used for short, high trajectories.
A group of geese, swans or other birds when they are in flight in a V formation.
One of a pair of wedge-heeled shoes.
A quantity of money.
definitions.example: I made a big fat wedge from that job.

definitions.definition: A sandwich made on a long, cylindrical roll.
definitions.example: I ordered a chicken parm wedge from the deli.

definitions.definition: Háček
The IPA character ʌ, which denotes an open-mid back unrounded vowel.
The symbol ∧, denoting a meet (infimum) operation or logical conjunction.
A wedge tornado.
A market trend characterized by a contracting range in prices coupled with an upward trend in prices (a rising wedge) or a downward trend in prices (a falling wedge).
To support or secure using a wedge.
definitions.example: I wedged open the window with a screwdriver.

definitions.definition: To force into a narrow gap.
definitions.example: He had wedged the package between the wall and the back of the sofa.

definitions.definition: To work wet clay by cutting or kneading for the purpose of homogenizing the mass and expelling air bubbles.
Of a computer program or system: to get stuck in an unresponsive state.
definitions.example: My Linux kernel wedged after I installed the latest update.

definitions.definition: To cleave with a wedge.
To force or drive with a wedge.
To shape into a wedge.
(Cambridge University slang) The person whose name stands lowest on the list of the classical tripos.

Political influence that is extended by means of diplomacy, media, international assistance, cultural exchanges, etc., rather than by such "hard" means as military intervention or punitive economic measures.
As sharp as a razor; extremely sharp.
definitions.example: The executioner was proud that he kept his axe razor-sharp, so no prisoner would feel any pain when his head was cut off.

definitions.definition: Very clever or quick-witted.
A medium used to bind pigments in painting, as well as the associated artistic techniques.
A painting done in this medium.
(often pluralized) The alimentary canal of an animal through which food passes after having passed all stomachs.
One of certain subdivisions of this part of the alimentary canal, such as the small or large intestine in human beings.
Domestic; taking place within a given country or region.
Internal.
Depending upon the internal constitution of a body or entity; subjective.
Shut up; enclosed.
A flat gong (without knob) that is struck with a felt-covered hammer.
A small joined pair of drums, beaten with the hands.
(usually as a pair) Any cylindrical drum, with no snare; part of a drum kit.
To play the tom-tom (pair of drums).
An oven or furnace or a heated chamber, for the purpose of hardening, burning, calcining or drying anything; for example, firing ceramics, curing or preserving tobacco, or drying grain.
To bake in a kiln.
definitions.example: When making pottery we need to allow the bisque to dry before we kiln it.

definitions.definition: An arousal.
The sounding of a bugle in the morning after reveille, to signal that soldiers are to rise from bed, often the rouse.
To wake (someone) or be awoken from sleep, or from apathy.
To cause, stir up, excite (a feeling, thought, etc.).
definitions.example: to rouse the faculties, passions, or emotions

definitions.definition: To provoke (someone) to action or anger.
To cause to start from a covert or lurking place.
definitions.example: to rouse a deer or other animal of the chase

definitions.definition: To pull by main strength; to haul.
To raise; to make erect.
(when followed by "on") To tell off; to criticise.
definitions.example: He roused on her for being late yet again.

definitions.definition: An official ceremony over drinks.
A carousal; a festival; a drinking frolic.
Wine or other liquor considered an inducement to mirth or drunkenness; a full glass; a bumper.
A physical exercise performed by thrusting the legs fully backwards from a squatting position with hands on the floor.
The source of a river, the set of streams that feed into the river's beginning.
To not select; to rule out of selection.
To reject (an MP) as constituency candidate at a forthcoming election.
To remove from an existing selection.
definitions.example: Make sure you deselect any files you wish to keep before proceeding with the deletion.

definitions.definition: The state or emotion of being sad.
An event in one's life that causes sadness.
definitions.example: She has experienced many sadnesses in her forty years.

definitions.definition: A dark blue colour, almost black.
Of a dark blue colour, almost black.
Something placed before another
To determine beforehand; to set in advance.

Rising or swelling in waves.
Full of waves.
Moving to and fro; undulating.
Having wave-like shapes on its border or surface; waved.

Having a color pattern resembling many small speckles of black and white.

definitions.definition: To shine; to make a surface very smooth or shiny by rubbing, cleaning, or grinding.
definitions.example: He polished up the chrome until it gleamed.

definitions.definition: To refine; remove imperfections from.
definitions.example: The band has polished its performance since the last concert.

definitions.definition: To apply shoe polish to shoes.
To become smooth, as from friction; to receive a gloss; to take a smooth and glossy surface.

definitions.definition: To refine; to wear off the rudeness, coarseness, or rusticity of; to make elegant and polite.
Made smooth or shiny by polishing.

definitions.definition: Refined, elegant.

The placenta and other material expelled via the birth canal following childbirth or parturition in mammals.

To draw with a crayon.
Excessive vanity, pride or arrogance; self-importance.

Pertaining to the game of billiards.

definitions.definition: A chosen course or direction for motion, as of an aircraft.
A carrier of a disease-causing agent.

A recurring psychosocial issue that stimulates growth and development in the personality.
The way in which the eyes are drawn across the visual text. The trail that a book cover can encourage the eyes to follow from certain objects to others.

A one-dimensional array.
A graphical representation using outlines; vector graphics.

To redirect to a vector, or code entry point.
Causing or meriting shame or disgrace; disgraceful
Giving offense.

A confection containing extract of peppermint.
The state of being virulent.
A measure of how virulent a thing is.

The study of homemaking, including cookery, needlework, cleaning, etc.

To row a boat using a scull or sculls.
To skate while keeping both feet in contact with the ground or ice.

The main bones of the head considered as a unit; including the cranium, facial bones, and mandible.
